children.subject: Yeah, it may be a course you could self teach if you really really wanted to learn UX/UI, especially since its pretty easy to pick up the relevant tools used (front-end web languages or front-end application languages and libraries, or even purely design tools like figma or adobe suite) to actually implement interfaces. The more difficult part is learning good design and human computer interaction ideas, but perhaps you can find course notes or read up on this in some other way, then just complete your own projects and build a personal portfolio. None of this is a great subsititute for the teamwork experience and you wont get immediate feedback the way you could if you took 160, but there are other ways to develop these skills. Consider also courses in other departments which also offer similar classes (Information dept, New Media, sometimes Architecture courses, and other design courses and professional education departments).

I find myself in the same boat where design classes at Berkeley have super limited enrollment, so I'll leave the student answer for someone who has a more direct answer to your question.

I highly recommend the Human-Centered Design DeCal (https://berkeleyinnovation.org/hcd-decal) or Web Design DeCal (https://wdd.io/) if you haven't taken those! (Disclaimer: I teach WDD).  Personal projects are also a great way to improve your UI/UX design skills. I'm happy to answer more questions about web/UI/UX stuff if you'd like!

history.content: I'm a sophomore CS major who's interested in going into UI/UX or HCI stuff in the future, but it doesn't seem likely I'll be able to take CS 160 next year (or maybe even senior year) because of how popular it is. I see that NWMEDIA 262 (Theory and Practice of Tangible User Interfaces) is being offered in the fall. Has anyone taken this or know if its a decent alternative to getting exposure in UI/UX? I'm unfamiliar with taking grad classes and idk how many undergrads they even let in.
history.subject: classes to take when you can't get into 160/ wanna learn more about UI/UX?
